pente

Class Player

  • java.lang.Object
    • pente.Player
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AIPlayer

    public class Player
extends java.lang.Object
    This class represents a human Player on the Pente board. For an AI Player, see the AIPlayer subclass.
    Author:
    eric_ferrante

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Player(java.awt.Color c, java.lang.String n, int id)
      Creates a new human Player with the given Color, name and player ID.
      Player(java.lang.String iconFileName, java.lang.String n, int id)
      Creates a new human Player with the given icon image file, name, and player ID.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Player

        public Player(java.lang.String iconFileName,
              java.lang.String n,
              int id)
        Creates a new human Player with the given icon image file, name, and player ID. Icon files should be put into the "images" folder of the Pente project.
        Parameters:
        iconFileName - The filename for your player icon. Ex: "black.png"
        n - The name of your player. Ex: "Boboman"
        id - The unique player ID for your player.

      • Player

        public Player(java.awt.Color c,
              java.lang.String n,
              int id)
        Creates a new human Player with the given Color, name and player ID. Icon files should be put into the "images" folder of the Pente project.
        Parameters:
        c - The Color of your player. Ex: Color.black
        n - The name of your player. Ex: "Boboman
        id - The unique player ID for your player.

    • Method Detail

      • makeMove

        public Location makeMove(int[][] idArray,
                         int moveCount)
        Used by AIPlayer subclasses to select a move on the board. To look at the board, analyze the idArray to see which players have pieces where. moveCount tells you which move of the game this is.
        Parameters:
        idArray - Represents the Pente board as an array of player IDs. An ID of zero means that spot is empty. Any other number represents the ID of the player in that spot. You can compare entries to your own ID by comparing it to getID() of yourself. If (idArray[r][c] != 0 AND idArray[r][c] != getID()) then it means your opponent has a piece at [r][c].
        moveCount - Which move of the game this is. If moveCount is odd, it means you are the first player and moveCount represents which move of the game this is (1, 3, 5, 7, ...) Likewise, if moveCount is even, it means you are the second player.
        Returns:
        A Location you want to move to on this turn.

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the name of this Player
        Returns:
        The name of this Player

      • getColor

        public java.awt.Color getColor()
        Returns the Color of this player if this player was constructed by the constructor that uses a Color instead of an image file.
        Returns:
        The Color of this player or null if this player was created using an image.

      • setMyCaptures

        public void setMyCaptures(int myCaptures)
        Sets the number of captures you have made.

        Note: The game sets this for you. Setting it yourself has no effect on the actual number of captures the game knows you have.
        Parameters:
        myCaptures - The number of captures you have made.

      • setOpponentCaptures

        public void setOpponentCaptures(int opponentCaptures)
        Sets the number of captures your opponent has made.

        Note: The game sets this for you. Setting it yourself has no effect on the actual number of captures the game knows your opponent has made.
        Parameters:
        opponentCaptures - The number of captures your opponent has made.
